text: It’s 1958. We’re in a lonely motel room. A key hits the lock. A MAN throws open the door and races into the room. He slams the door. He peeks out the window and studies the parking lot. He struggles to catch his breath. We may notice blood on the sleeves of his suit. This is FELIX O’ KELLY. He steps away from the window. He’s carrying a RED DUFFEL BAG. He sets it down and surveys his room.

Felix shoves the bed to the side of the room. [Note: for the duration of this sequence, the camera rema in the same position. Fast jump cuts.] Felix opens his red duffel bag. He removes a crowbar. A hammer. A handgun.
Felix, his jacket off now, yanks up the carpet from the corner of the room, revealing the WOODEN FLOOR BOARDS bel Felix looks at the floor boards. Looks at his tools. Thinks.

Felix adjusts THE RADIO antenna. Static. He fiddles with the dial. Fifties folk-pop fills the room as Felix finds station playing “26 Miles” by The Four Preps. Twenty-six miles across the sea, Santa Catalina is a-wait for me... Felix turns up the volume.
Felix hammers the crowbar between slats in the center of room. The sound is somewhat muffled by the radio. (CONTINUED)
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 2.
He pries up the floorboards one by one.

Santa Catalina, the island of romance, romance, romance.. We may notice it’s NIGHT outside now. Felix has his shirtsleeves rolled up. He’s covered in sweat. There’s no a large hole in the floor. The floorboards are all neatly stacked to the side. Felix zips up the duffel bag. We never get a good look at what’s inside. He drops the bag inside the hole.
Felix replaces the floor boards. He hammers the nails in time to the music. He smokes while he works.
Felix rolls the carpet back. Stamps it down in the corner He looks down at the hammer in his hand. Looks at the crowbar on the bed. Thinks.
The room is empty now. Through the open door, we can see it’s raining outside. We hear a trunk SLAM.

A soaking wet Felix crawls on his hands and knees and sco up the sawdust on the carpet. He stands. Surveys the room Looks good. Felix catches a glimpse of himself in the LARGE MIRROR mounted on the wall. Looks less good.
Felix stands in front of his mirror. He combs his hair wi a black plastic comb. Twenty-six miles across the sea...
(CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 3.
Felix paces back and forth. He stubs out one cigarette an lights another.

Felix sits in the wooden chair in the corner. He smokes. The ashtray next to him is filled with butts. HEADLIGHTS flare the curtains. Felix stubs out his cigarette. Forty kilometers in a leaky old boat... There’s a knock at the door. Felix grabs the handgun from the night stand. Moves to th peephole. Studies the outside world. Any old thing that'll stay afloat... His shoulders relax when he sees who it is. Felix throws the latch. Opens the door. Gestures for the person to come on in... BOOM. A shotgun BLAST hits Felix O’Kelly square in the ba He’s launched clear across the room, and the second his b SLAMS INTO CAMERA, blood splashing the lens --
Bad Times At The El Royale Over black. Title clears. A new song ("25 Miles”) signals new era. Driving sixties soul as Edwin Starr calls out, “ right, feet, start moving..." TITLE: Ten years later

The El Royale is a motor lodge nestled in the woods north Lake Tahoe. It once had dreams of being a mid-level vacat hideaway. Those dreams do not appear to have been realize “You've got to get me there...” A wooden arch bears the name of the establishment, welcom visitors to the mostly-empty parking lot. A dented gray Studebaker drives through the arch. (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 4.

The defining characteristic of the parking lot is A RED L that bisects the lot dead center and leads straight to th double doors of the lobby lodge. “It's twenty-five miles from home..." The Studebaker parks. The driver opens her door. We get a better look at her: Late thirties. African-American. As she stares at the El Royale, we can almost hear her thinking, “How in the Lord name did I end up in this lonely place?” This is DARLENE SWEET. She opens her trunk and removes HER ODD BAGS. One is a la flowered suitcase. The other appears to be an enormous ro of fabric, bound with a rope around it. It would be too much luggage for a lumberjack, let alone Darlene. But she lifts the burden without complaint, balancing one in each arm. As she approaches the lodge, she notices A MAN standing i the parking lot: He’s in his sixties. He’s wearing a priest collar. He’s staring at the hotel. He looks lost and confused. This is FATHER DANIEL FLYNN. Darlene slows when she sees him.
Are... you lost, Father? Flynn almost jumps when he hears her. His eyes become cle again, as though he just awoke from a dream. He smiles.

No. No, I suppose not. (looks down) According to this, I’m in Nevada. ON THE GROUND: the RED LINE runs right between them. On t west side of the line, stenciled letters read “California On the east side of the line, “Nevada.”
(smiles ) I’ve never been to Nevada. What’s it like? (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 5.
Not bad. Looks like it might rain. What’s California like? Darlene looks over her shoulder to the west.
Still sunny. Flynn picks up his valise.
Can I give you a hand there?

That's very kind of you, thank you. She hands him the flowered suitcase. If Flynn is curious about the strange roll of fabric in Darlene’s arms, he gi no indication. They walk towards the motel. The border leads straight to set of doors, one door on each side of the line. They enter through the California side.

Ring-ring. The front door chimes as Darlene and Flynn ent and study the unique accommodations: The interior of the El Royale plays on the same border th The line bisects the large room perfectly in two. ON THE CALIFORNIA SIDE: everything is decorated in warm orange hues. We may notice a bar, a set of tables, a loun seating area. ON THE NEVADA SIDE: everything is decorated in cool purpl hues. We may notice the front desk, some gaming tables, a black and white television currently showing coverage of Richard Nixon’s 1969 inauguration speech. At the back of the room, half in California and half in Nevada, is a colorful JUKEBOX. Flynn looks down at the border, Darlene follows his gaze. They're both standing in California. Flynn gestures: be m guest. Darlene smiles. Takes a mock deep breath... And steps across the border. (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 6.
How are you enjoying Nevada so far? Darlene shrugs. So far, so good.

Those are my accoutrements... The voice has a thick Mississippi accent. It’s coming fro behind the bar on the California side. A man wearing a charmingly rumpled seersucker suit reveals himself: This is LARAMIE SEYMOUR SULLIVAN.
(points) At the front desk there. They look to the front desk, where a large amount of lugg has been piled.

That’s my trunk, that’s my fortnighter, that’s my hat case. And I’d ask that you folk respect my claim when it comes time to divvy the rooms. Though when that'll be is anyone’s guess. I been ringin’ that bell so long my hand’s sore and my ears is tired and my constitution needs coffee. So. That’s why I’m back here scroungin’. He holds up a pack of coffee grounds. He dumps it into th elaborate machine behind the counter.
Success! Though I can’t say I vouch for the quality. He starts the machine. While it grinds and grumbles, Lara crosses the room, extends his hand to Flynn.

Laramie Seymour Sullivan. Sales manager, Calhoun Appliances. My name may not be on the masthead, but that don’t mean it ain’t a family business. He hands Flynn a business card. Tips his hat to Darlene. (CONTINUED)
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 7.
Ma’am.
Hello.
What should I call you, Father?
Daniel Flynn. It is nice to meet you.
Father Flynn, huh. That’s easy to remember, alliterative and such. Whereabouts is your parish?
The Immaculate Heart of Mary’s in Bloomington, Indiana. A beat as Laramie sizes up Flynn.

Well. (then) Let me just say up front that me and the good people of East Biloxi Baptist may have our differences with your Pope, but in our hearts we both believe in the divinity of Jesus Christ, and that makes us brothers as far as I’m concerned. Who handles your hospitality at the Heart of Mary?
I'm sorry?
You know, who keeps the place clean and tidy?
Her... name is Barbara.
Could I trouble you for Barbara’s phone number? I believe the good Lord has put me in your path to make her life easier. (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 8.
Flynn studies Laramie. Thinks.
I confess my memory is not what it used to be. But I have it written down in my valise. I'd be happy to get it for you once I check-in and am squared away.
I'd sure appreciate it. Though, again, Lord only knows when that'd be. He points to the brass bell on the front desk.
You can go ahead and give it a whirl. I ain’t had much luck with it. (turns) How ‘bout you, darlin’ -- you in the hospitality business? Darlene seems genuinely taken aback.
I -- how did you know my name?
Your name is “Darlin’?” Ain’t that a pip! And they say fate died in ‘63. Darlene realizes the mistake.
Oh. Sorry. I thought you said... never mind. I’m not in the hospitality business. No.

Well, I’1l give you my card nonetheless. I’m sure you know some gals who need a vacuum. A beat. Then Father Flynn rings the bell. The group waits in awkward silence. No response. Laramie rolls his eyes: see what I mean? (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 9.
This your first time at the El Royale? Both Flynn and Darlene nod. Laramie crosses back to the b

It didn't always used to be like this. And I don’t jus’ mean you could find the clerk come check-in. Naw, this place used to be hustlin’ and bustlin’. Tahoe’s best kept secret. I mean, it was always a novelty, but there’s state fair novelty and old horse novelty and we are now firmly in the old horse variety. He removes the coffee carafe from the machine and grabs t cups. As he starts making his way back across the room:
‘66 this place had swing. Hell, I’m sure I couldn’t get a main lodge room if I tried. He points to the photographs adorning the California wall

It was a hidey hole for the Tahoe swells. Darlene looks at the photos. The El Royale in more boisterous times. There’s Frank Sinatra lounging by the pool. There’s Martin Luther King, Jr. shaking hands with crowd of well-wishers. There’s Bobby Kennedy making pop- superstar VESTA SHEARS laugh.
Dean Martin even sang a song about it. “Half In California With Judy?” (off their looks) No? (shrugs) Wasn’t one of his best. Coffee? Flynn nods. Sure. Darlene shakes her head.
No, thank you. (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 10.
Aw, come on. I made a whole pot. Can’t let it go to waste. He hands her a cup. Take it. She relents.

(as he pours) Atta girl. I'll let the clerk give you the whole spiel, should he ever show up, I mean. But the part they tend to leave out is about, oh, a year ago this place lost its gambling license. Some problems with the commission or something. And so the swells took their business elsewhere. Now the main lodge is all that’s open and the pool is filled with ducks and they rent rooms by the hour if you ask quiet-like. (then) ‘Course, if we’re bein’ honest, that’s probably why a priest, a vacuum salesman, and a Negro can afford freight here, right Father? (laughs) I’m just funnin’. My stay’s on Calhoun Appliances, if I’m bein’ truthful, which is why room choice is so important and I ask you to respect my accoutrements there as a proxy for my person. I intend to lavish myself. Always wanted to stay in The Honeymoon Suite. He holds up his left hand. His ring finger is bare.

Though I am not currently on my honeymoon. They wait in awkward silence. They sip their coffee. A light bulb goes off over Flynn's head. As though he’s b thinking about something else this entire time:
Oh. (turns) “Darlene.” Darlene nods. Smiles. (CONTINUED)
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 11.
FATHER FLYNN (CONT’D) Nice to meet you, Darlene.
Nice to meet you too, Father.

Well, hell. We have to wait much longer, I might as well open up that there trunk and set up the Calhoun Electrovax. Give you folks a proper demonstration. You sure you ain’t in the hospitality business, darlin’? Darlene, once again, shakes her head.
No, sir. I am not. She walks behind the front desk to THE DOOR that says “Employees Only.” Gives it a proper thumping with her fis Wham wham wham. There’s a THUD from behind the door.

Ho! The lady’s got a luckier hand than we do, Father. Shame these here tables is decommissioned, we could make ourselves some real money. We hear fumbling. Footsteps. The door finally swings open revealing a twenty-year-old kid with a baby face and an i fitting desk clerk jacket. He looks a bit like a wet rat. This is MILES MILLER.
I’m very sorry to keep you waiting. If you had to guess how long it has been since Miles has slept, you'd probably go with “Five days.”
Damn, boy, I been in this lobby so long, I’m due for a shave. What's wrong with you?
I'm very sorry. (CONTINUED)
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 12.
Miles stops cold. If it’s possible for him to go paler, h does when he sees Father Flynn. MILES (CONT’D) Wh... what are you doing here, Father? Flynn seems genuinely unsettled.
Do I know you, son?
No. But... I mean... this is not a place for a priest, Father. You shouldn’t be here.
We may need to work on your sales pitch, boy. “The El Royale: Ain't No Place For A Priest.”
There are other hotels, Father. Maybe closer to Tahoe? I could help you find one, I’m sure you'd be happier there. Flynn recovers. Smiles a patronly smile. Looks at Miles’ name tag.
“Miles,” is it? If this is not a place for a priest, Miles, then this is exactly where the Lord wants me.

Well, the Lord don’t want you in The Honeymoon Suite, I promise you that much. Miles, those is my accoutrements there, and I stake my claim as such. But you can go ahead and check them in first for all I care. (looks in mirror, rubs chin) Any luck I'll have a full Jeb Stuart by the time we’re done. Miles looks back and forth between Laramie and Flynn. He continues to seem genuinely anxious. (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 13.
It’s all right, son.
Go ahead, boy. Give ‘em the spiel. “The El Royale...”
The El Royale is a bi-state establishment. You have the option to stay in either the great state of California OR the great state of Nevada. Which would you prefer?
What’s the difference?
Between California and Nevada?
Between the rooms.
Well, for starters, rooms in California cost a dollar more.
(whistles) Shoot. Really. When that happen? What makes ‘em a dollar better?
They're in California.
And that’s worth a dollar?
Some people think so.
You got a number for those people? ‘Cause I got a vacuum they might be interested in. Speaking of which! Who’s your Head of Hospitality here?
Currently that is also me. (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 14.
(grimaces) Well. Then let’s worry about that later then.
May I see a map of the hotel? Miles nods. He pulls out A MAP. From above, the El Royale looks like an upside-down “U” with the parking lot in the middle. As Father Flynn looks it over --
Only the main lodge is available in the off-season. (then) You can still use the California amenities if you choose to stay in Nevada.
(chuffs) What exactly is a “California amenity?”
For instance, we are not allowed to sell liquor in Nevada.
Lost that when you lost your gamblin’ license? So, you’re saying, if we want to drink, we gotta do it on this side of the room?
That’s correct, sir. Also, coffee is twenty-five cents a cup.
Let me guess, you’re also the bartender.
That’s correct, sir. Laramie rolls his eyes. Removes a quarter from his pocket Slaps it on the desk next to Flynn, who seems genuinely rattled by the map. (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 15.

Feel free to flip that if you need to make a decision, Father. Starting to cost me money waitin’ around here. The quiet of the lobby is suddenly disturbed by the ROAR an engine from outside. All four people turn towards the windows to see a GREEN DODGE CHARGER scream into the lot. Tires SQUEAL as the Charger screeches to a stop. Flynn turns his attention back to the map. Shakes his hea Picks up Laramie’s quarter and flips it. Heads. Shrugs.

I‘1l take Room Four. Miles looks away from the window. Gets a key from the wal behind him. Laramie moves closer to the window for a better look. IN CAR: we can make out A WOMAN in the driver’s seat. She se to be watching the road behind her intently.

I‘1l need one night in advance. Eight dollars. And twenty-five cents for the coffee. Please sign the ledger. There’s a large leather ledger on the desk. Flynn takes o $8.25 and puts it on the counter. Picks up the fountain p CLOSE AS HE SIGNS: Father Daniel Flynn. MILES (CONT’D) Who’s next? Laramie is still interested in the car outside. He gestur to Darlene. Go ahead. She steps forward.
I'd like a room in Nevada, please. Miles nods. Grabs a key. Slaps it on the desk.
Room Five.
(uncomfortable) Oh. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 16.

(then) Is there another room available, possibly? Further away. Maybe at the end? OUTSIDE: the car door slams. The WOMAN starts walking towards the lodge. She’s in a hurry. Laramie turns his attention back to the desk.
These rooms have not been serviced and are unsuitable.
He does the housekeeping, remember.
There are rooms in California available, ma’am.
(losing patience) She doesn’t want to be near the priest. Flynn, who was collecting his belongings and moving to ex stops in his tracks. I’m sorry?

(to Flynn) Like we don’t see her walkin’ in here with her own bedrolls under her arms. (to Darlene) Don’t worry, darlin’, we ain’t here to judge. Father here can even teach you ‘bout Mary Magdalene and forgiveness and what not. Darlene’s eyes flash with embarrassment and anger. Ring-ring. Right then, the woman from outside walks into El Royale. She's in her late twenties. Looks to be a card-carrying member of the flower generation. She’s trying her best no to look distressed. And failing. This is EMILY SUMMERSPRING. Emily stops in her tracks, not expecting to find this man people in the lobby. What did I just walk into? (CONTINUED)
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 17.
Darlene turns her attention back to Miles, eager to get o of there. She takes a small coin purse from her jacket an counts out eight one-dollar bills.
Room Five will be fine.
Please sign the ledger. And it’s twenty-five cents for the coffee. Darlene’s eyes instinctively look to Laramie. He’s not making eye contact.

(quietly) Okay. Of course. As she starts to reach for her coin purse. Clack. A hand puts a quarter on the desk. Darlene sees it belongs to Flynn. He nods. It’s on me. Darlene nods back. Thank you. She grabs the pen. CLOSE ON THE LEDGER as she writes: Darlene Sweet. She grabs her bags.
Can I give you a hand to your room?
No. She stops herself, realizing this man is not the one who deserves her anger.
Sorry, Father. That’s kind of you. But I can manage from here. Ring. Laramie makes a show of holding the door for her.
(tips hat) Ma’am. Flynn waits a beat. Gathers his valise. Moves to leave. Nods to Emily as he passes.
Afternoon. (CONTINUED)
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 18.
She gives him a curt nod. Ring. Flynn exits. And then there were three. Miles looks to both of them. Who's next? Laramie just shakes his head. Throws up his hands.
Please. Be my fuckin’ guest. (yells to window) Sorry, Father. Emily shrugs. Fine. I'll go. Steps forward.
I need a room.
The El Royale is a bi-state establishment. You have the option to choose a room in either -- She grabs the map from the desk. Studies it. Taps it.
I‘1ll take that one. Miles looks down at her choice. His shoulders slump just slightly. His weary eyes look back to Laramie.
Don’t fuckin’ tell me. Emily removes a large wad of cash from her jeans.
I‘1l take Room One.
You can’t have Room One. Emily turns and stares at him. Defiant. Why not?

Do you see my fortnighter right there at your feet? Is this really happening? (to Miles) Am I really about to explain the concept of a free market claim stake to the goddamn hippie? Emily just stares at him with cold eyes. (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 19.
Then she relents. Turns back to the map.
Give me something along this wall.
The available rooms on that wall have yet to be cleaned.
I don’t give a shit. How much?

Eight dollars. She peels off eight dollars. He puts a key on the desk. Room Seven. She reaches for it. He slides it away. MILES (CONT’D) Please sign the ledger. Emily stares at him. Really? He stares back. Yes. She grabs the pen. Scrawls something fast. Grabs the key. Heads towards the door. Ring.
You have yourself a pleasant day, now. Laramie steps forward. Finally. He grabs the pen. Looks down at the ledger. Sees Emily’s signature.

Nice. CLOSE ON THE LEDGER: Fuck You. Laramie signs his name at the bottom of the page. CLOSE ON THE LEDGER as he writes with flourish: Laramie Seymour Sullivan. CLOSE ON LARAMIE as he looks up at Miles and smiles.
I‘1l take Room One. CUT TO BLACK. TITLE: Room One  Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 20.

We hear the sound of a key jangling. Click. Laramie enter hits the lights. He carries his accoutrements into the ro Takes off his hat and jacket. Folds the jacket carefully lays it over the back of a chair. Rolls up his white shir sleeves. Studies the room. The Honeymoon Suite is on the California side of the bord and thus decorated in warm orange hues. It would never be described as luxurious by any means, but it does have a notable king bed on a raised platform and a jacuzzi tub i the floor. CLOSE SHOTS: locks flip. A suitcase swings open, revealin neatly folded clothes. Everything feels regimented. A han removes A DOPP KIT. CLOSE SHOTS: items are placed along a sink. A toothbrush. soap case. A small bottle of shampoo. A hair tonic. All meticulously ordered just so. CLOSE SHOTS: locks flip. The trunk swings open, revealing the Calhoun Electrovax. The vacuum is removed. Click. A false bottom is removed from the trunk. A BLACK BRIEFCASE removed and placed on the bed. The briefcase swings open, revealing an array of SMALL TOOLS. CLOSE SHOTS: a pair of glasses are removed from a case. Laramie sits on the bed. In his shirtsleeves and wirefram glasses now, he looks a far cry from the seersucker southerner we met moments ago. He removes a pair of pliers and a screwdriver from the ca He thinks of something. He checks his watch. Does a small double take. Picks up the phone and dials it. Listens. Then.
Hi, my love. I know, I know... check-in took a little longer than I expected... And as Laramie talks, we may notice that his thick Mississippi accent is now GONE.
Is she still up? (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 21.
While Laramie waits, he takes the screwdriver and begins unscrew the baseplate of the phone receiver. He works quickly, with clinical precision.

Hi rabbit! I know, I’m sorry. I got delayed. Yes, the clock is right. Daddy's wrong. And between the accent, the wife, the child, and the tool it should obvious that this man has not been honest about he is. In fact, we should probably start calling him by h real name. This is not Laramie Seymour Sullivan... This is DWIGHT BROADBECK.
But I got you before you went down. Ready? Of course. I’m on my knees. Dwight pulls off the baseplate, flips the housing over. Looks under the receiver...
“Now I lay me down to sleep, pray the Lord my soul to keep...” Dwight removes a SMALL BLACK MICROPHONE from the receiver Holds it up to the light. Nods, pleased. He sets it down the night stand.

“And if I should die before I wake, I pray the Lord --” (listens) What do you mean we’re not saying that anymore? (listens) How do you even know what “morbid” means -- what does Mommy want us to say? Dwight begins to reassemble the phone.

Okay. “When I wake in the morning light --" Okay, okay, from the beginning... Dwight frowns. Something’s WRONG. He holds the receiver u to the light to get a better look. Grabs his pliers. (CONTINUED )
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 22.
“Now I lay me down to sleep, pray the Lord my soul to keep. And when I wake in the morning light...” Dwight removes something else from the phone with the pli Holds it up to the light.
“Teach me to do what’s right.” It’s another microphone. This one’s different than the other. Smaller. Tan in colo Dwight stares at it, confused. Clearly troubled.

Amen. (then) I gotta go, Rabbit. Tell Mommy I love her, okay? (listens) A couple days. I love you. He hangs up. Places the tan bug on the night stand next t the black bug. Stares at the two different microphones. His eyes narrow. He looks to the rest of the room.

Dwight stands on the armchair. Unscrews the wall sconce. Reaches behind the light with a pair of pliers. CLOSE SHOT: an identical black bug is placed beside the first. Dwight pulls the light fixture from the wall. Frowns. CLOSE SHOT: an identical tan bug is placed beside the fir

Dwight’s in the bathroom now. Covered in sweat. Unscrews the light. Frowns. CLOSE SHOT: Four black bugs are now on the night stand. Dwight’s hand places a fourth tan bug in the row beneath And then a fifth tan bug.
(CONTINUED)
Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 23.

Dwight stands in the center of the room. Arms folded. Staring at the night stand covered in surveillance bugs. Deep in thought. He shakes his head. None of this makes sense. He turns. Something catches his attention. And the hair stands up o the back of Dwight’s neck. We follow his gaze... To the large MIRROR mounted on the back wall. In the reflection, he can see a full view of the bed in t center of the room. Dwight stares at the mirror. Thinks.

CLOSE: A brown shoe steps carefully through the pine twig A second shoe steps directly in front of it, placing heel front of toe. Dwight, still in shirtsleeves and glasses, walks carefull along the east edge of the El Royale. Heel-to-toe. Heel-t toe. Heel-to-toe. He's measuring the hotel. Dwight reaches the corner. Folds his arms. Stares at the hotel. Thinks.

Ring-ring. Dwight steps into the lobby. Looks the place over. It’s empty. The black and white television is still on, casting flickering pale light all around the room. ON THE TELEVISION: a SPECIAL NEWS REPORT breaks into the Nixon coverage. We see shots of police cars outside a lar mansion. News logo reads: “Malibu Beach Massacre.” Dwight opens the front desk drawer. Sees the room keys. Spots THE MASTER. He takes it. Dwight unlocks the door marked “Employees Only.” He eases the door open...

Dwight steps into the narrow hallway. We can hear music coming from somewhere. “Bend Me Shape Me” by The American Breed. Dwight surveys. At the far end of the hallway, there’s a HEAVY METAL DOOR. (CONTINUED )
10 11 12 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 24.
Closer to Dwight, there’s another door with the words “MAINTENANCE CLOSET.” “Bend me shape me anyway you want me..."

Dwight eases the door open, looks into the room. His face falls. Reverse to reveal -- A cramped closet. A cot. A hot plate. A transistor radio. And Miles. Passed out cold. Slumped against the wall. A bent spoon on the floor beside him. A syringe still hangi from his bloodied arm. “As long as you love me, it's all right..." Dwight closes the door.

Dwight approaches the HEAVY GRAY DOOR at the end of the hallway. Tries the handle. It’s LOCKED. He tries THE MASTER KEY. It doesn’t work. Dwight reaches into his pocket. Pulls out a case of LOCKPICKS. Drops to his knees. Works the lock. Click.

Dwight steps into a dimly-lit corridor. Shuts the door behind him. Music stops. The world goes silent. Dwight steps carefully down the corridor. At the end of t corridor, the corridor branches. West or East. Dwight chooses West. Careful not to make a sound. Rounds the corner... And finds the mirror. Or, rather, the OBSERVATION WINDOW. perfectly framed rectangle looking into a hotel room. Specifically... His hotel room. He stares at Room One. Arms folded. Thinks. Looks down at the feet. Takes note of THREE SCUFF MARKS on the floor.  13 Bad Times At The El Royale Final Shooting Draft 25.

We used to raise goats out on the farm. Boer goats, ‘cause you can breed ‘em year round. Bucks are ready to go once they’re about seven weeks old. Seven weeks! (looks to Wade) Can you imagine?
